claim: Newton and Leibniz jointly discovered calculus

supporting.text: Historical records show that Newton developed his method of fluxions (calculus) in the mid-1660s, while Leibniz developed his differential and integral calculus independently in the mid-1670s.

attacks.text: Historical records show that Newton developed his method of fluxions (calculus) in the mid-1660s, while Leibniz developed his differential and integral calculus independently in the mid-1670s.
There is evidence that Leibniz may have seen some of Newton's unpublished manuscripts during his visit to London in 1676, raising questions about the complete independence of his work.
The priority dispute between Newton and Leibniz suggests that their contributions were not entirely independent, as both accused each other of plagiarism.
The Royal Society's 1712 report, which favored Newton, was biased as Newton himself presided over the investigation, undermining its objectivity.
Leibniz's notation and methods were more widely adopted and practical than Newton's, indicating his work had independent value regardless of any prior knowledge.
Modern historians of mathematics generally agree that both Newton and Leibniz made significant, independent contributions to the development of calculus.
